full_title: We've Had Enough by Michael Jackson
lyrics:
Love was taken from a young life
And no one told her why
Her direction has a dim light
From one more violent crime

She innocently questioned why
Why her father had to die
She asked the men in blue
How is it that you get to choose
Who will live and who will die
Did God say that you could decide?
You saw he did not run
And that my daddy had no gun

In the middle of a village
Way in a distant land
Lies a poor boy with his broken toy
Too young to understand

He is awaken, ground is shaking
His father grabs his hand
Screaming, crying, his wife is dying
Now he is left to explain

He innocently questioned why
Why his mother had to die
What did these soldiers come here for?
If they are for peace, why is there war?

Did God say that they could decide
Who will live and who will die?
All my mama ever did
Was try to take care of her kids

We are innocently standing by
Watching people lose their lives
It seems as if we have no voice
It is time for us to make a choice

Only God could decide
Who will live and who will die
There is nothing that cannot be done
If we raise our voice as one
 
They have got to hear it from me
They have got to hear it from you
They have got to hear it from us
We cannot take it
We have already had enough
Deep in my soul baby
Deep in your soul and let God decide
Deep in my soul
It is up to me and I am still alive
They have got to hear it from us
We cannot take it
We have already had enough
It is going down baby
Just let God decide
It is going on baby
Just let God decide
Deep in my soul baby
We have already had enough
title: We’ve Had Enough

full_title: What More Can I Give by Michael Jackson (Ft. 3LW, Aaron Carter, Anastacia, Beyoncé, Billy Gilman, Brian McKnight, Bryton James, Carlos Santana, Céline Dion, Gloria Estefan, Jon Secada, Justin Timberlake, Luther Vandross, Mýa, Mariah Carey, Michael McCary, Nick Carter, *NSYNC, Reba McEntire, Ricky Martin, Shakira, Shawn Stockman, Thalía, Tom Petty, Usher & Ziggy Marley)
lyrics:
How many people will have to die before we will take a stand? How many children will have to cry, before we do all we can?
If sending your love is all you can give
To help one live
How many times can we turn our heads
And pretend we cannot see
Healing the wounds of our broken earth
We are one global family
Just sending your prayers
Is something you'll feel
Helping one heal

What have I got that I can give?
What have I got that I can give?
(Tell me)
What have I got that I can give?
To love and to teach you
To hold and to need you
What more can I give?

Brother to brother lay down our fears and reach out and make a pact
Show him the love that is in our hearts let us bring salvation back
Just sending your love has the power to heal
So let's all give

What have I got that I can give?
(Is not allowed to give just a little bit)
What have I got that I can give?
(Everyone should be a part of it)
To love and to teach you
To hold and to need you
What more can I give?

Say the words
I'll lay me down for you
Just call my name
I am your friend
See, then why do they keep teaching us
Such hate and cruelty?
We should give over and over again

What have I got that I can give?
(We should give over and over again!)
What have I got that I can give?
(Oh my god, oh my god)
(Oh my Lord)
See, to love and to teach you
To hold and to need you
What more can I give?
What have I got that I can give?
What have I got that I can give?
(give you, give to you)
See, to love and to teach you
To hold and to need you
What more can I give?
What have I got that I can give?
(What More Can I give?)
What have I got that I can give?
(I wanna give to you, give it to you)
See, to love and to teach you
To hold and to need you
What more can I give
(they think I'm wasting my time now)
What have I got that I can give?
(To give it to you, we wanna give to you
What have I got that I can give?
To hold and conceal you
To love and to heal you
What more can I give?
(Give me, give me one time more)
What have I got that I can give?
(What I got, what have I got)
(Say your prayers)
What have I got that I can give?
(Show the world how much you really care)
To love and to teach you
(To love you, teach you)
To hold and to need you
(To hold you, to need you)
(What more?)
What more can I give?
What have I got that I can give?
(What can I give? Tell me what can I give you)

lyrics:

lyrics:
And now a behind-the-scenes treat from the original voice-over session for "Thriller", with Michael and Vincent Price. You'll also hear the never-before-released second verse of Vincent's rap, written by Rod

Okay, tape's rolling. Any--anytime you want

Hi, this is Michael Jackson
This is Vincent Price
Michael Jackson is...
The Thriller!

*Vincent laughs*
Do we both say it?
Say it together?
"Inviting you to."
I say "inviting you to"? All right. Yeah
Okay
Any time. Tape's rolling

Hi, this is Michael Jackson
And this is Vincent Price, inviting you to...
The Thriller!

Darkness falls across the land
The midnight hour is close at hand
Creatures crawl in search of blood
To terrorize your neighborhood
And whosoever shall be found
Without the soul for getting down
Must stand and face the hounds of hell
And rot inside a corpse's shell

The demons squeal in sheer delight
It's you they spy, so plump, so right
For though the groove is hard to beat
Yet still you stand with frozen feet
You try to run, you try to scream
But no more sun you'll ever see
For evil reaches from the crypt
To crush you in its icy grip

The foulest stench is in the air
The funk of 40,000 years
And grisly ghouls from every tomb
Are closing in to seal your doom
And though you fight to stay alive
Your body starts to shiver
For no mere mortal can resist
The evil of the Thriller

Can you dig it?
Hmmm-Hahahahaha...
AHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!
AHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA
Ahahahahahahah...

Hmmph, that's great fun!
Great, thank you. Cut
Okay. All right!

full_title: Planet Earth (Poem) by Michael Jackson
lyrics:
Planet Earth, my home, my place
A capricious anomaly in the sea of space
Planet Earth, are you just
Floating by, a cloud of dust
A minor globe, about to bust
A piece of metal bound to rust
A speck of matter in a mindless void
A lonely spaceship, a large asteroid
Cold as a rock without a hue
Held together with a bit of glue
Something tells me this isn't true
You are my sweetheart soft and blue
Do you care?
Have you a part?
In the deepest emotions of my own heart
Tender with breezes caressing and whole
Alive with music, haunting my soul
In my veins I've felt the mystery
Of corridors of time, books of history
Life songs of ages throbbing in my blood
Have danced the rhythm of the tide and flood
Your misty clouds, your electric storm
Were turbulent tempests in my own form
I've licked the salt, the bitter, the sweet
Of every encounter, of passion, of heat
Your riotous color, your fragrance, your taste
Have thrilled my senses beyond all haste
In your beauty, I've known the how
Of timeless bliss, this moment of now
Planet Earth are you just floating by, a cloud of dust
A minor globe, about to bust
A piece of metal bound to rust
A speck of matter in a mindless void
A lonely spaceship, a large asteroid
Cold as a rock without a hue
Held together with a bit of glue
Something tells me this isn't true
You are my sweetheart gentle and blue
Do you care, have you a part
In the deepest emotions of my own heart
Tender with breezes caressing and whole
Alive with music, haunting my soul
Planet Earth, gentle and blue
With all my heart, I love you
title: Planet Earth (Poem)

lyrics:
As I drove across on the highway
My jeep began to rock
I didn't know what to do, so I stopped, then got out, and looked down, I noticed I've got a flat
So I walked out, parked the car, like sideways
So I can find, what I can fix
I looked around, there were no cars on the highway
I felt a strange feeling, like a mist
So I walked down, toward the end of the road
And in the fog, a woman appeared
She said don't you worry my friend, I'll take care
Take my hand, I'll take you there

Take me to a place without no name

Take me to a place without no name

As she took me right through the fog
I saw a beautiful city appear
Where kids are playing and people are laughing and smiling and nothing to fear
She says this is the place where no people have pain, with love and happiness
She turned around, looked down in my eyes, and started crying, and grabbed my hand, you've got a friend

Take me to a place without no name

Take me to a place without no name

Take me to a place without no name

Take me to a place without no name

She started liking me, kissing me, and hugging me
She didn't really, really want me to leave
She showed me places I've never seen, and things I've never done, it really looked like a lot of fun
I've seen the grass, and the skies and the birds, and the flowers, surrounded by the trees
This place is filled with love and happiness, how in the world, could I wanna leave
So then I went in my pocket, took my wallet all out
With my pictures of my family and girl

full_title: 68  different Michael Jackson songs by Michael Jackson
lyrics:
"GRIOT"S LAMENT" applies Michael Jackson's lyrics to the artists' ongoing exploration of metamorphosis as a threshold of change, and as medium for identifying political and social injustices . " An innocent black man was killed, and we are that injustice" sang Michael alongside his sister Janet in the song SCREAM. I use "recontexualization" of these lyrics to revisit the killings of Trayvon Martin, Oscar Grant, and the countless number of innocent youths that have fallen prey to violence in Southwest Chicago. "They don't care about us" was shouted as a veiled response to the Rodney King beating , but could it have also been a foretelling or foreshadowing of the tragic humanitarian failures incurred during Hurricane Katrina? One violent scene in the film will be staged to replicate the horrific Rodney King beating. The film asks the question, as Michael did repeatedly via his music: How culpable are WE... when society cannot fully function in the realm of justice? The character "Griot" is the conduit for Michael's often overlooked and under recognized political orientation, a perspective that is often over shadowed by the glow and power of his popular music and larger than life persona. "Griot", pictured here and played by actor Brandon Hirsch, is a one man Greek chorus; "A broken ear witness to unspeakable crimes ". I am blessed and grateful to have an amazing crew and unbelievably talented cast whose creative currency will super charge every pixel of every single frame. As a team of artists, we are especially excited about hiring (with the help of our partners) local youth from Inglewood and South Central Los Angeles to work on the film, so that they can benefit from the experience of participating in a local professional film production.  Formerly incarcerated Youth from my non profit  FYI FILMS  Films by Youth Inside,  which empowers incarcerated youth via story telling  and digital film making worked as both talent and crew on this GL! ! Lastly, I'm grateful to have the support of  Black Hollywood Education Resource Center. I began writing Griot's Lament the night that Michael left us. In my heart , it is my sincere hope that Griot's Lament is a fitting tribute to the King of Pop, whose music is the soundtrack to much of my life.
Mini Review of Griots Lament by Akello Stone
"These days we are bombarded with lots of visual media, stories and messages in the forms of videos. Most of it is completely unimaginative but Griot's Lament is much different It truly is a short-form "theatrical experience on the small screen" that evokes thoughts with the kind of intellectual depth, auditory stimulation and cadence, and visual creativity that many of us so desire. It truly captures the wonder, the suspense, the social commentary that can draw you in and leave you sitting - wanting more." Bravo!
And from Nathan Hale Williams
Click below for full article with photos or read text below
http://nathanhalewill.com/trayvon-martin-revisited-via-michael-jacksons-lyrics-in-griots-lament/
Trayvon Martin Revisited Via Michael Jackson’s Lyrics in “Griot’s Lament”
JULY 16, 2014 • ENTERTAINMENT, FEATURED • VIEWS: 221
There’s a new trend in entertainment, repurposing the lyrics of artists like Tupac (Holler If Ya’ Hear Me on Broadway) and now, a new web series, Griot’s Lament does the same with the King of Pop’s lyrics.  It is excellently done and one of the most innovative web series that I’ve seen in a long time and it comes from director, Aleks Munoz.
Here is what the Director had to say about his latest effort, “My next film “GRIOT”S LAMENT” applies Michael Jackson’s lyrics to the artists’ ongoing exploration of metamorphosis as a threshold of change, and as medium for identifying political and social injustices .”
An innocent black man was killed, and we are that injustice” sang Michael alongside his sister Janet in the song SCREAM. I use “recontexualization” of these lyrics to revisit the killings of Trayvon Martin, Oscar Grant, and the countless number of innocent youths that have fallen prey to violence in Southwest Chicago.

“They don’t care about us” was shouted as a veiled response to the Rodney King beating , but could it have also been a foretelling or foreshadowing of the tragic humanitarian failures incurred during Hurricane Katrina? One violent scene in the film is staged to replicate the horrific Rodney King beating. The film asks the question, as Michael did repeatedly via his music: How culpable are WE… when society cannot fully function in the realm of justice?

The character “Griot” is the conduit for Michael’s often overlooked and under recognized political orientation, a perspective that is often over shadowed by the glow and power of his popular music and larger than life persona.  I began writing Griot’s Lament the night that Michael left us. In my heart , it is my sincere hope that Griot’s Lament is a fitting tribute to the King of Pop, whose music is the soundtrack to much of my life.”
The film uses formerly incarcerated youth, as both talent and crew  from Munoz’s FYI FILMS by Youth Inside, which empowers incarcerated youth via story telling and digital film making.

Before you judge me, try hard to love me
The painful youth I've had

full_title: The Musical Influences Of Fabrejay Growing Up by Michael Jackson
lyrics:
Fabrejay is an accomplished and world renowned persona with roots planted firmly and deep in the music industry. Born as Jeffrey Santana, he has not only entered the apex of the worldwide DJ scene, but has also pursued various prosperous producing and entrepreneurial endeavors as well. The DJ knew early on in his life that he was determined to turn his passion for music into a full blown career and lifestyle, and did exactly that with both elegance and class. Regarded as a highly sought after DJ, Fabrejay has a long list of famous clients, which includes the likes of Rihanna, Diddy, Former President Barack Obama, and celebrity couple Beyonce and Jay-Z. Fabrejay performs on a regular basis at some of the hottest venues and events around the world. Currently, the DJ holds the honorable position of brand ambassador for the alcohol company D’usse Cognac, in addition to holding a residency as well as being the official DJ of Jay-Z’s exclusive celebrity hot spot nightclub, The 40/40 Club, located in New York City, NY. 
Fabrejay’s story is a modern reflection of the vast and ever-evading American Dream, and he emphasizes in his music and speech the need for every individual to chase the success they feel they deserve and should have. The talented DJ has worked with some of the best in not only the hip hop world, but also in the music industry as a whole. There doesn't seem to be anything stopping this talented individual from ascending the ladder into greatness, and perhaps one day joining the likes of his celebrated clients and musical heroes. 
However, being an accomplished artist does not just begin and end with the individuals themselves. Musical influences also play a major role in what direction the artist chooses to pursue, and what roads he will take. Without having those key voices surrounding you growing up, one would not be turned on to the type of things that could be done in the future of the industry. Fabrejay has a variety of different influences that he has stated helped him get to the level where he is now. Growing up, Fabrejay had found inspiration through a number of different genres of music. The main ones which caught the attention of the DJ at an early age included Latin, Oldies, Top 40, and Hip-Hop. However, Fabrejay has found that three main artists had the most influence on him, and opened his eyes to possibilities he had not seen before. They represent a soundtrack for various stages in his life, and have been more influential to him during his early days than any other artist, each marking a special era in his life. 
Here we have listed the top 3 musical influences of the Fabrejay. Perhaps one day, they could guide the next generation on their journey as well. 
Michael Jackson 
Michael Jackson gained enormous popularity throughout his life as an acclaimed singer, dancer, and songACwriter. Starting off as a member of a sibling singing group known as “The Jackson Five,” personal talent, drive, and a motivating family influenced the young singer to branch off and make his own way as a solo performing artist. Michael Jackson soon began releasing his own music. This led to hit album after hit album, which contained such recognizable and world famous musical hits like “Beat It,” “Billie Jean,” “Man in the Mirror,” and “Thriller.” Jackson was even one of the first to create a cinematic music video experience for his audiences, which featured storylines and a variety of famous people involved in the overall process. Some of these celebrities included Martin Scorsese, Paul McCartney, Chris Tucker, Macaulay Culkin, and John Travolta. Michael Jackson eventually became known as one of the greatest entertainers in the entire music history, and went on to earn some of the highest accolades in the industry. Dubbed simply as the “King of Pop,” he was acknowledged as one of the best selling artists 
of all time. Though Jackson passed away in 2009 at the early age of 50, he is still known around the world for his music which emphasized togetherness, environmentalism, and fighting against the prejudices and injustices of the world. 
Fabrejay, like many other people at the height of Michael Jackon's music, has stated that the singer and songwriter was his introduction to music. His dance moves had caught the world by storm, and influenced the young Fabrejay growing up, shaping the young man's mind to a significant degree about the possibilities that remained in the music industry. The DJ states that the infamous “Smooth Criminal” song, as well as it's accompanying music video, was one of his favorites of all time. Through “Smooth Criminal,” Jackson was also able to contribute to Fabrejay's own fashion sense and clothing options. As a fan of sneakers, Fabrejay to this day considers the Air Jordan 11 Concord to be his favorite among all of the other Jordan sneakers currently on the market. This is because they gave the DJ vivid memories of Michael Jackson's anti-gravity shoes containing spats, which Jackson had used in his “leaning” dance moves in the music video for “Smooth Criminal.” 
In regards to his admiration for the acclaimed singer and songwriter Michael Jackson, Fabrejay says, “He was so creative and his music is timeless, he reached unthinkable heights. There’s really so much inspiration when it comes to MJ.” 
Like many up and coming artists, as well as established celebrities in the music industry, Michael Jackson remains a favorite. 
Tupac Shakur 
Tupac Shakur, who was also known by his stage name 2Pac, was an American rapper and actor. Tupac was born in New York City and later moved to Baltimore Maryland and then Marin City, California. This constant moving played deep in his music. The rapper became a central figure in rap, eventually releasing the critically acclaimed and successful albums “2Pacalypse Now,” “Me Against the World,” and “All Eyez on Me.” He solidified himself in the rap scene, with many of his songs reflecting the “thug” lifestyle. Many people still consider Tupac Shakur as one of the greatest rappers in the history of music, proven by the amount of famous collaborations with the rapper both before and after his death in 1996. 2Pac’s songs were highly thought provoking and deep, touching on the struggles and social issues that faced much of the lower classes, as well as the overall inequality between people in general. The rapper remains one of the best selling artists of all time, and has also appeared in a variety of noteworthy movies, such as “Juice,” “Poetic Justice,” and “Gridlock’d.” His acting was praised by movie critics as well as his fellow cast members. 
Fabrejay has stated that Tupac was an artist that highly influenced him throughout the progression of his own musical career. He admired Tupac's ability to possess so much raw energy, and to release that energy into his songs and music. He became captivated not only by the music being made, but also Tupac's persona and what he stood for as a human being. For Fabrejay, Tupac’s songs and the accompanying 
lyrics had a strong and bold message written between every word and behind every beat, which forced the world to listen to the music through strength and grit. 
In speaking about Tupac, the DJ has said, “He’s a timeless artist. You feel as if he’s still around because the stuff he’s talking about is still relevant to date.” 
And the number of accolades the artist has received, and his popularity among people still hold that as a valid truth, hopefully for many, many years to come. 
Jay Z 
When one thinks of the music industry as a whole, the name Jay-Z is impossible to escape. Jay Z is a renowned rapper, songwriter, entrepreneur, and record executive. Born in New York City and hailing from Brooklyn, the musical artist started rapping at a young age. But it wasn't until he founded his own record label, Roc-A-Fella Records, in 1995 that he started to gain notoriety from the masses. He is one of the first rappers to utilize his business acumen in addition to his rapping skills to become successful. Jay-Z began with the release of his studio album “Reasonable Doubt” in 1996, and he instantly gained celebrity status, eventually going on to drop hit after hit through his key albums “The Blueprint” and “The Black Album.” The artist even released two albums, “Watch the Throne” and “Everything is Love,” with fellow rapper Kanye West and his wife Beyonce, respectively. Aside from music, the rapper had gone on to have a very successful business career, by founding his own clothing retailer, opening a sports bar, creating an entertainment company, as well as engaging in other lucrative ventures. These business choices all led Jay-Z to become the the first billionaire of the hip hop industry, and he is currently also the wealthiest musician on the planet. However, his backbone is his music, with the world considering him one of the world's best-selling music artists. He has acquired a large number of awards throughout the years, including Grammys and Billboards. He was also acknowledged in the Rolling Stones magazine as one of the 100 Greatest Artists of All Time. 
Fabrejay has very fond memories of the rapper Jay-Z being the backbone of his youth. He has stated that Jay-Z has been the “it” artist from his younger days until now, and has provided the soundtrack musically from his early years to date. Fabrejay also admires the fact that Jay-Z was able to remain at the top of the charts throughout his career, something that other artists find is more difficult to achieve. He sees Jay-Z as one of the most important symbols in the music industry. There is also an admiration for his personality and the vibe he brings to the world, not just the crowds he performs to. His business acumen is another thing that Fabrejay regards as something he looks upto about the artist, utilizing his teachings to learn what can and cannot be done in the path of pursuing success. As a DJ in the music industry who has made a name for himself as well, it would only make sense that he follows one of the prime examples of success In an industry that topples many other weaker artists. 
This is what the DJ had to say about Jay-Z: “He’s broken and continues to break barriers. Just the length of his career shelf life serves as inspiration in itself. He's remained true to himself throughout it all and continues to elevate gracefully. Jay's a genius. I'm blessed to work under the umbrella of my hero.” 
Jay-Z is definitely a strong person worth admiring at an early age, and you could guarantee it shaped Fabrejay to become the success he is now. 
As you can see, an artist's greatness is only as strong as the influences he had growing up. It's how the individual shapes those traits and ideas he learns that makes him unique and successful in his own right. Fabrejay's influences vary in style. Michael Jackson has a more mainstream and pop oriented feel. Tupac speaks more about social issues and preaches how to rise from poverty. Jay-Z pushes the envelope in music, talking more about mainstream struggles and pop culture phenomenon. Regardless of these differences, it's clear that a combination of worthy admiration was necessary for Fabrejay in creating his own interpretation of greatness. The acclaimed DJ has a style all his own, and it reflects these influences as well as a variety of others. Fabrejay is continually building himself, and only time will tell what the artists can and will achieve. 
REFERENCED ARTISTS 
FABREJAY 
MICHAEL JACKSON 
TUPAC SHAKUR 
JAY-Z
title: The Musical Influences Of Fabrejay Growing Up
